posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked:
Where do teams get the rollers that they use on intakes and conveyor systems. They look like hard plastic, but all I could find is the Versa Roller from Vex, which is a foam.

I’ve also heard about dead axles and it seems like those make the process simpler, but I can’t see how to mount them.

Do any companies sell a kit that is used for larger diameter rollers? Is it possible to 3D print an adapter between a bearing and a pvc tube to mount it?

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
A couple of different places sell similar items.

Dead axle setups have multiple ways to be mounted. You can use a hex shaft or round bar as a shaft, then the tube has a bearing in it that allows it to rotate around the shaft.

ETA: Kickoff This kit is great for driving your 1.125" ID x 1.25" OD tube of choice. Includes two aluminum hex bore parts with two 10-32 threaded holes and four 10-32 button head bolts to secure tubes to the hubs. This kit provides enough parts to...

Price: USD 12.99

This new kit from Thriftybot allows you to drive 1.125" ID tubing in a number of ways. Using the Thrifty Metahub, plug into tubes and use your bearing bore of choice. Kit includes all of the following -  - QTY 2 Aluminum Thrifty Metahubs - 24...

Price: USD 39.99

Behold! The RoboRollerz Kit! The Roller bundle to rule them all. In this bundle you receive:   6x RoboRollerz - Carbon Fiber Roller (RB-RR001) 1x  RoboRollerz - Drill Jig (RB-RR002) 8x RoboRollerz End - 1/2 Hex Blind (RB-RR003) 8x...

Price: CAD 499.99

The tubing itself is polycarbonate tubing. It’s commonly found on McMaster

McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.

link_counts.title: Thrifty Dead Axle Tube Roller Kit
Thrifty Live Axle Tube Roller Kit

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked:
For the rollers, MCM sells polycarb tubes. 1/16in wall or 1/8in wall works fine.

For deadaxle rollers, you have a few options. 1678 and 254 have some pretty good rollers that work well, i personally prefer the one at parts.frccad.com made by @AndrewCard

You just have to print 2 endcaps, and use standard 1/2 or 3/8 hex with the associated bearings. You can mount them through the tapped hole in the axle. The benefit of a deadaxle means it can double as a standoff between plates.

You can also use PVC pipe as the roller, but you would have to adjust the cap to accommodate the different ID.

If you want them COTS , TTB recently released some.

Let me know if there is anything else you need to know, i <3 deadaxle rollers.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
Just found the ones made by @AndrewCard ! Looks awesome!

Any chance we could allow the pullies to go to smaller tooth counts? They are currently limited at 24 as the minimum.

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked: I believe it is set to that to ensure you can fit a standard 1.125OD 1/2in hex bearing, as any smaller either breaks it or leaves so little material around the bearing that it becomes really sketchy.

posts.name: Peter
posts.cooked:
VEX has come out with a new roller system that makes deadshaft intake rollers super easy. The hubs attach to bare tube by tightening 3 #8-32 screws, and VEX also sells brand new polycarbonate tubes that have silicone pre-stretched around them to increase the grip on game elements.

Ankur-Raghavan:

I’ve also heard about dead axles and it seems like those make the process simpler, but I can’t see how to mount them.

You can see examples of using these hubs in a dead shaft application in the “details” tab at the bottom of the page.

Ankur-Raghavan:

Do any companies sell a kit that is used for larger diameter rollers?

These tubes are 2" diameter which is great for intakes. https://www.vexrobotics.com/intake-components.html

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked: But in live axle setups without the bearing in the rollers you can go much smaller. My take on most of these configurable assemblies is keep the options wider, which puts the onus on the user a bit more to prevent breaking stuff. To each their own though.

posts.name: Brendan Conover
posts.cooked: That’s fair, a big driving point behind Andrew’s development it looked like was to make it so it could not break.

posts.name: Taiga
posts.cooked: For this deadaxle style, how is the axle attached to sideplates? It seems like the hex shaft would be rotating while trying to tighten the screw.

posts.name: Neel M
posts.cooked:
You just bolt the shaft on both sideplates, it shouldn’t rotate if your hex is tapped. If its rotating then u can clamp it with a vice or something:

image 1495×938 129 KB

image 1495×938 129 KB

image 1495×938 129 KB

Onshape (link)

The roller itself rotates because of the bearing
